The next piece of evidence is supplied, not by a bio- grapher of Dante, but by a fifteenth-century historiam, namely Flavio Biondo of Forh, who in his Historiarum ab inclinato Romam Imperio DecadeS, which was com- pleted in or about the year 1440, states that he had seen at Forh letters written by Pellegrino Calvi, secretary of Scarpetta degli Ordelaffi, the Ghibelline leader in Forh, which had been dictated by Dante, and in which Dante’s name frequently occurs—‘ Peregrini Calvi foroliviensis, Scarpettae epistolarum magistri, 'extantes literae, crebram Dantis mentionem habentes, a quo dictabantur’ ;‘·' and in another passage he makes special mention of a letter written by Dante in his own name and in that of the exiled Bianchi to Can Grande della Scala at the time of the advent of the Emperor Henry VII into Italy, in which Dante gave an account of the insolent reply re- turned by the Florentines to the ambassadors of the Emperor—a letter of which, as Biondo tells us, a copy was taken by Pellegrino Calvi—‘Dantes Aldegerius, Forolivii tunc agens, in epistola ad Canem Grandem Sca- ligerum veronensem, partis Albae extorrum et suo nomine data, quam Peregrinus Calvus scriptam reliquit, talia dicit de responsione a· Florentinis urbem tenentibus tunc facta '.³
